column4: In the process of setting up Postfix I learned that my ISP blocks outgoing port 25.  I'm able to receive mail just fine via port 587.  I'm a noob when it comes to Postfix.  Is it necessary for it to be able to connect to port 25 or can I change that outgoing port to 587?
your ISP will likely block any outbound mail protocols, regardless of port...
for any *stable* mail server, you should use 25 for the mail port, and 587 for receiving mail
I asked them (at&t) in a live chat and they told me port 25 was the on one being blocked.
i was unaware they still provide non-wireless internet services
In the Austin Texas area they provide DSL.
you could always use a gmail account or something to send mail, and depending on what is using postfix, that should fix the mail-sending issue...

That's what I do.  I was setting up a mail server really for educational purposes so if I ever had to role out my own email I could.  It's a non issue I was just annoyed they where even blocking that.  But it's understandable why they want to stop spam being most customers are none IT people and a lot of them are infected spam bots.
She wanted me to upgrade to a business account to unblock the port.  I was like, thanks but no thanks.
that's really the only way to unblock that port, for *any* residential provider

So from I understand is that for SMTP mail servers to function they all have to making outgoing port 25 connections to communicate to each other regardless if you're using SSL/TLS and that's pretty much the standard workings of SMTP servers?

So when one mail server relays email to another email server it's doing it on port 25?  In clear text?  I thought the whole point of using SSL/TLS for the mail server was so no one can sniff the traffic and read your email.
its using port 25, as for SSL/TLS, its probably using another port encrypted
since you're delving into server jargon and confusing your concepts...
don't assume i know the inner workings of postfix.  But usually it won't send SSL/TLS'd stuff via plaintext
the people who are definitely more knowledgeable might be in #ubuntu-server, or you can wait here for one of their people to answer you in better detail
